data.text:
Synopsis

Although the first Academy Awards ceremony was held in 1929, it looks very different today than it did during its inception. Initially, the Oscars awarded two films with the 'Best Picture' trophy; and the award for 'Outstanding Picture'. Know about the iconic actor who founded the Oscar Awards.

The 2024 Oscar Awards will be held on Sunday, March 10, at the Dolby Theatre at Ovation Hollywood. These awards are given to celebrate all aspects of a film’s production, including crafts that tend to get less media attention. While celebrating films, it is natural to remember actor, comedian, and stunt artist, Harold Lloyd played, who played an important role in founding the Academy Awards. During the time of all-time greats like Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton, Lloyd was one of the most popular comedy stars of the 'silent era' of Hollywood. It was a critical period in the development of the film industry that proved that the medium was both commercially viable and artistically rewarding and led to the emergence of great cinema within the 1920s.

Huge loyal fan of Harold Llyod

Harold Llyod enjoyed a huge loyal fan base due to his signature personality. Though his films and shorts varied in terms of story, and rarely shared any continuity, they generally reflected the ambitions and struggles of general people as the protagonist found himself caught up in inordinately chaotic circumstances.

Llyod establishes Academy Awards

Lloyd joined a group of actors and filmmakers in 1927 and founded the Academy Awards of Motion Pictures Arts & Sciences. He was joined by such noted artists as Douglas Fairbanks, Jack Warner, Cecil B. DeMille, and Raoul Walsh. They believed that public recognition of cinematic crafts would help generate respect for the industry and create a board of artists.

First Oscar Awards

Although the first Academy Awards ceremony was held in 1929, it looks very different today than it did during its inception. Initially, the Oscars awarded two films with the 'Best Picture' trophy; and the award for 'Outstanding Picture'. The ceremony also distinguished its Best Director award between Best Directing (Comedy Picture) and Best Directing (Dramatic Picture). The Academy has added and changed many categories in the years since, but awards like Best Actor, Best Actress, and Best Cinematography have remained the same.

Harold Lloyd Gets Honorary Award

Though Harold Lloyd never received any competitive awards, the iconic actor got an Honorary Award in 1953 for being "a master comedian and good citizen." Honorary Awards are often used by the Oscars to reward artists whose work never received the attention it deserved at the time of their release.
